articles.headline: AllianceBernstein Ousts C.E.O. and Shakes Up Board
articles.snippet: The reshuffling comes as investors increasingly abandon active money managers in favor of less expensive exchange-traded funds.
articles.abstract: The reshuffling comes as investors increasingly abandon active money managers in favor of less expensive exchange-traded funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that highlights the increasing pressures faced by stock pickers on Wall Street, Peter S. Kraus, the chief executive of AllianceBernstein Holding, was ousted by the money manager’s controlling shareholder on Monday.

articles.headline: With Fox News in Tumult, Another Executive, Bill Shine, Is Ousted
articles.snippet: The removal of a co-president, a holdover from the Roger Ailes era, continued a housecleaning prompted by a sexual harassment scandal.
articles.abstract: The removal of a co-president, a holdover from the Roger Ailes era, continued a housecleaning prompted by a sexual harassment scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News forced out one of its most senior executives on Monday, the latest aftershock of a sexual harassment scandal that has engulfed the television network and pressured its owners, the Murdoch family, into a painful and protracted public housecleaning.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Trump’s Volatility in Asia Distresses a Longtime U.S. Ally: Australia
articles.snippet: Some in Australia worry about the risk of being drawn into a conflict that forces it to side with either the United States, its military ally, or China, its biggest trading partner.
articles.abstract: Some in Australia worry about the risk of being drawn into a conflict that forces it to side with either the United States, its military ally, or China, its biggest trading partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARWIN, Australia — South Korea, Japan and the United States have grown accustomed to North Korea’s diatribes, but Pyongyang recently threatened a new target with a nuclear strike: Australia.

articles.headline: TV Station Owners Rush to Seize on Relaxed F.C.C. Rules
articles.snippet: A vote by the Federal Communications Commission last week sets the stage for the consolidation of local television stations in a deal-making frenzy.
articles.abstract: A vote by the Federal Communications Commission last week sets the stage for the consolidation of local television stations in a deal-making frenzy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The media industry has been rife with consolidation in recent years: Cable companies, film studios and telecommunications firms have all been bought and sold at a rapid clip.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Trump Follows Instincts, Not Establishment, With Overtures to Kim and Duterte
articles.snippet: President Trump‘s willingness to meet with the North Korean and Philippine leaders illustrated his confidence in his own deal making but alarmed critics.
articles.abstract: President Trump‘s willingness to meet with the North Korean and Philippine leaders illustrated his confidence in his own deal making but alarmed critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump continued his outreach to rogue leaders on Monday, declaring he would meet North Korea’s dictator, Kim Jong-un, provided the circumstances were right, even as the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte, brushed aside the president’s invitation to visit the White House, saying he might be “too busy.”

articles.headline: Will Trump ‘Do a Big Number’ on the Big Banks?
articles.snippet: Wall Street shuddered as President Trump, for the first time as resident of the White House, mused that he was considering breaking up the largest banks.
articles.abstract: Wall Street shuddered as President Trump, for the first time as resident of the White House, mused that he was considering breaking up the largest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a brief moment, Wall Street stopped on Monday, as if time was suspended in an alternative reality.

articles.headline: With Civil War Remark, a President Who Doesn’t Go by the (History) Book
articles.snippet: The president’s comments about the Civil War underscored what seems to be a tenuous understanding of the events that preceded his ascension to power.
articles.abstract: The president’s comments about the Civil War underscored what seems to be a tenuous understanding of the events that preceded his ascension to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If nothing else, President Trump has already secured a place in history. It is his grasp of history that seems less secure.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jonah Engel Bromwich

articles.headline: Ivanka Trump Has the President’s Ear. Here’s Her Agenda.
articles.snippet: The first daughter has the president’s trust and a widening portfolio. So what will she do with it?
articles.abstract: The first daughter has the president’s trust and a widening portfolio. So what will she do with it?
articles.lead_paragraph: A month before Donald J. Trump was elected president, he and his aides watched his daughter’s coolly composed surface crack open.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor, Rachel Abrams and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Infosys, an Indian Outsourcing Company, Says It Will Create 10,000 U.S. Jobs
articles.snippet: The pledge, light on details, follows big promises by other Asian employers to create American jobs in the era of President Trump.
articles.abstract: The pledge, light on details, follows big promises by other Asian employers to create American jobs in the era of President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facing new corporate demands and political pressure from a Trump administration that wants to curb immigrant work visas, Infosys, one of India’s leading tech outsourcing companies, said Tuesday that it will hire up to 10,000 Americans to serve its clients in the United States.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: To Understand ‘Brexit,’ Look to Britain’s Tabloids
articles.snippet: Despite their falling circulations and tarnished reputations, tabloids maintain a striking grip on power as Britain prepares to cut ties with the European Union.
articles.abstract: Despite their falling circulations and tarnished reputations, tabloids maintain a striking grip on power as Britain prepares to cut ties with the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tony Gallagher, editor of The Sun, one of Britain’s most raucous and influential tabloids, looks down on the government, literally. From the height of his 12th-floor newsroom, all glass and views, the Palace of Westminster seems like a toy castle, something to be played with or ignored at will.

articles.headline: Trump and Putin Agree to Seek Syria Cease-Fire
articles.snippet: In their first conversation since last month’s rupture over Syria, President Trump said he would send a representative to Russian-sponsored talks.
articles.abstract: In their first conversation since last month’s rupture over Syria, President Trump said he would send a representative to Russian-sponsored talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump reopened direct communications with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday and sought to reignite what he hoped would be a special relationship by agreeing to work together to broker a cease-fire in war-torn Syria.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Microsoft Looks to Regain Lost Ground in the Classroom
articles.snippet: Google, with its low-cost and easily maintained Chromebooks, has steadily taken school customers away from Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Google, with its low-cost and easily maintained Chromebooks, has steadily taken school customers away from Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Last week, Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, slipped on a glove made of cardboard and clenched his hand into a fist, causing a robotic hand with fingers made of drinking straws to mimic his movements.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: G.O.P. Eyes $8 Billion Addition to Win a Crucial Vote to the Latest Health Bill
articles.snippet: Representative Fred Upton of Michigan said he wants more money to protect people with pre-existing medical conditions endangered by the latest health care repeal bill.
articles.abstract: Representative Fred Upton of Michigan said he wants more money to protect people with pre-existing medical conditions endangered by the latest health care repeal bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With two days left before an 11-day recess and no vote scheduled, House Republican leaders considered last-minute changes to their latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday, including at least $8 billion in extra spending to answer the concerns of an influential Republican who had come out against the measure.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer, Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear
